prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We plan to characterize the G5.97-1.17 proplyd by, first, imaging its associated disk and, second, derive electronic density and temperature. We are interested in comparing the properties of G5.97-1.17 with the properties of proplyds located in other regions. This will help to asses the role of environmental effects have on disk evolution and planet formation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We plan to set three basebands to observe the continuum emission (i.e. total continuum bandwidth of 5.6~GHz that provides an excellent sensitivity) plus a fourth one to observe the H30alpha line. All the basebands with be employed with dual polarization.
Typical linewidth values of recombination lines seen over compact objects inside HII regions comprise 20-30 km/s [14]. Since, as mentioned in the sensitivity justification, we do not require high spectral resolution, we plan to smooth the provided 0.97 MHz channel to 6.9 MHz (or to 8 MHz as a power of two i.e. one third of the linewidth, approximately). Thus, we plan set the maximum bandwidth available with the spectral mode (1.9 GHz). This will ensure that, despite being very wide, the line falls within the spectral window.

The estimated radius of the disk of the G5.97 proplyd is 160 AU [6] that, at 1.3 kpc of distance, corresponds to a total angular size of 0.25 arcsec. The angular resolution 0.1 arcsec will provide not only enough sensitivity to detect the disk, but also enough angular resolution to resolve it, at least, with the deconvolved dimensions. Fig. 3 we show the simulated observations as proposed here proving the viability of the observations. For the synthetic source, we used a Gaussian model of 0.25'' x 0.22'' of size (the expected two dimensional angular size of a 160 AU disk [8] oriented with the line of sight an inclination angle of 60 deg) and the arbitrary P.A. of 45deg. For the 1 mm continuum emission we adopted 1.5 mJy for the total flux corresponding to the less favorable case and for the recombination line we adopted 10 mJy. For the synthetic observations, we employed the CASA task 'simalma' and synthetic images were constructed with the task 'simanalyze'. We simulated 45 min of on source observing time (slightly less than the needed in this proposal) with the configuration C36-6 over a bandwitdh of 1.86~GHz and 15.6~MHz for the continuum and recombination line emission, respectively, and adopted 1 mm of PWV for the atmospheric conditions. The rms of the maps are consistent with the results of OT (the continuum simulated map has higher rms noise than the OT because it has a bandwith corresponding to one spectral window, i.e. 3 times narrower than the introduced in the OT and both maps are obtained with slightly less on-source observing time). Although the maps of Fig. 3 are obtained with natural weighing, we may use a different Briggs parameter for the continuum emission, which is expected to have better S/N than the recombination line emission, to gain angular resolution. This may depend on the quality of the data: for instance, under the assumed conditions, the inspection of the resulting simulated map suggest the natural weighting as the best choice.
We are interested in studying the compact sources of the M8 region. As seen in figure 1, G5.97, the largest source in the field, has an angular size of ~0.5 arscec. As a consequence, we do not expect to miss any important structure and, hence, ACA observations are not required (as the OT states) Also, the ALMA primary beam at 1 mm is large enough to cover our region of interest.

Based on an estimated evaporation timescale, Stecklum et al. (1998) [6] derived 0.06 Msun for the mass of the disk associated with the proplyd. This value provides a good reference to estimate the flux of the dust expected at 1 mm assuming optically thin emission and adopting a given temperature and a tabulated gas opacity. Typical dust temperature (20 K) yields to 1.5 mJy. However, due to photoelectrical heating caused buy the UV photons coming from Her 36, the disk might have a higher temperature. For instance, for this case, a few hundreds of kelvin yields to ~2.5 mJy. However, we will adopt the value of 1.5 mJy as the thermal dust emission at 1 mm in order to prevent underestimating the integration time. As we expect to resolve the source (0.25 arcsec of size) with our angular resolution (0.1 arcsec), we estimate that the flux will be distributed into 5.5 spatial resolution elements. This gives 0.27 mJy falling in a beamsize that, for a sensitivity of 17.5 microJy obtained in 60 minutes of on source integration time (obtained with the ALMA Observing Tool), implies a detection of the emission in the source with an average signal to noise ratio (S/N) of 15. Also, in the right panel of Figure 3 we measure 0.53 mJy/beam at the continuum peak position of the simulated map, that implies a detection with a maximum S/N of 30.
The ionized gas is expected to emit continuum free-free emission and recombination lines. At 1 mm we expect a major contribution for the later. Assuming optically thin conditions, probably reasonable at 1 mm, the ratio between the H30alpha line flux and continuum emission increases with frequency. Adopting an electron temperature (Te) of 10000 K and 25 km/s of linewidth we obtain a value of 2.7 for this ratio at 1 mm. In case of having lower Te and/or larger linewidth, we obtain an even larger ratio. Masque et al. estimated a free-free continuum flux of 5 mJy at 3.6 cm. In the case of having optically thin free-free emission with an spectral index of -0.1, we get 3.5 mJy at 1 mm. We recall that this value could be slightly higher in the case that the index is flatter. Applying the relation between the recombination line flux and continuum emission derived above we obtain 10 mJy as total flux for the H30aplha emission. As for the continuum emission, if we assume that the line emission is distributed over 5.5 spatial resolution elements, we get an average 1.8 mJy per beam. Since we are interested in detecting the line over the proplyd and not to measure the profile shape in detail, high spectral resolution is not an important request. Thus, we plan to smooth to 8.5 km/s channels (or 8 as a power of 2, i.e. one third of the linewidth, approximately). According to ALMA OT, with 60 minutes of on source integration time, and adopting an user specified bandwith of 8.5 km/s, we reach 0.52 mJy, that implies a detection with an average S/N of 3.5. However, as seen in the left panel of Fig. 3, the peak is 3.8 mJy (S/N ratio of 7) that ensures the line detection. In addition, in the case of having additional extended H30alpha emission along the proplyd, we plan to degradate slightly the angular resolution of the map (e.g. via UV tapering) aiming to recover any possible extended structure.
Adding the overheads, the ALMA OT gives 2 hr of total observing time.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: While most of the well-studied proplyds are located in Orion, the properties of proplyds associated with other regions appear to differ. We propose to observe the continuum emission at band 6 as well as the H30aplha recombination line of the M8 region, where a massive star (Her 36) photoevaporating a proplyd (G5.97) that presents non-thermal emission is found. With the proposed observations, we will, first, image the disk of the proplyd and derive its mass, size and orientation and, second, we will derive electronic temperature and density. We aim to characterize the G5.97 proplyd and compare it with proplyds found in other regions. This will shed light on the role of the environmental effects have on the evolution and planet formation of plotoplanetary disks.
